messageBody:
John Cowan wrote:
>
>
> Paul Tremblay scripsit:
>
> > That means we have to type an extra character when we type, something
> > pretty unnatural.
>
> Well, you get to decide whether x+y defaults to ligaturing or to not
> ligaturing, but there has to be some way to signal the difference.
> So it's either type a key to trigger ligaturing or type a key to
> suppress ligaturing -- your choice.

But that is an extra key, and not a natural one. If you want to type the
ligature Earth, right now you type one letter on the keyboard. (When
you are using the ASCII font.) There is a one to one correspondence. If
you want to type Ado Roar, there is a one to one correspondence for each
letter. Your way means typing in an obscure character. For laying out
books, the extra step doesn't mean much. For day to day correspondences,
it means either extra effort, or more likely, it not being used because
most users won't understand or won't bother.


> Kerning's a more advanced feature than ligaturing. Since you mention
> Word, I assume you're on Windows, and I don't know much about rendering
> on Windows.

Ligatures may be less advanced, but we are still at the mercy of the
table being read. When I mentioned Word, I meant Word on the Mac, since
that is all I have tried it on. But I also tried it on Open Office for
the Mac, Open Office for Linux, Firefox for both Mac and Linux, Safari
(Mac), and Tex Edit (Mac).

Paul
